notes: Conservative legume family expansion: peanut/soy/pea/bean/lentil relationships. Immunologic cross-reactivity is common but clinical reactions are less frequent.
Peanut and soy share Bet v 1 and 2S albumin homologs. Immunologic cross-reactivity documented; clinical co-allergy is less common than serologic overlap.
Lupin and peanut show strong cross-reactivity via vicilin and conglutin proteins. European labeling regulations already flag this relationship.
Low-level immunologic cross-reactivity between peanut and pea. Clinical reactions are infrequent.
Lentil shares some legume allergen families with peanut. Cross-sensitization documented but clinical significance variable.
Chickpea-peanut immunologic overlap has been reported. Clinical co-allergy is less common.
Soy and pea share legume allergen structures. Clinical cross-reactivity is infrequent.
Low immunologic overlap between soy and lentil through shared legume protein families.
Immunologic cross-reactivity among wheat, barley, rye, oat, and related cereal grains demonstrated. Clinical relevance varies by individual.
Wheat-barley cross-reactivity via shared prolamins (gliadin/hordein). Serologic overlap is well-documented.
Wheat-rye cross-reactivity via shared prolamin structures (gliadin/secalin). High serologic overlap.
Oat avenin has partial homology with wheat gliadin. Cross-reactivity is immunologically possible but clinical significance is debated; many celiac patients tolerate oats.
Spelt is a wheat species (Triticum spelta). Very high protein homology; cross-reactivity is expected.
Kamut (Khorasan wheat) is a wheat relative. High protein homology with common wheat.
Triticale is a wheat-rye hybrid. Contains prolamins from both parents.
Barley hordein and rye secalin share structural homology. Cross-reactivity documented serologically.
Malt is typically produced from barley. Contains barley prolamins; effectively the same allergen source.
Gluten is the primary allergenic protein complex in wheat. Direct compositional relationship.
Barley hordein is a gluten-related protein. Relevant for gluten-sensitive individuals.
Rye secalin is a gluten-related protein. Relevant for gluten-sensitive individuals.
Fungal allergens share conserved enzyme structures. Yeast, Aspergillus, Candida, and mushroom cross-reactivity documented via shared enolase and manganese superoxide dismutase epitopes.
Yeast (Saccharomyces) and Aspergillus share conserved enolase and MnSOD allergens. Cross-sensitization has been documented.
Saccharomyces and Candida are closely related yeast genera. Cross-reactivity through shared allergen structures is expected.
Yeast-mushroom cross-reactivity is possible via shared fungal allergens, but clinical significance is lower than within yeast genera.
Aspergillus mold and mushroom share some fungal allergen families. Clinical cross-reactivity is possible but not well-characterized.
Tree nut cross-reactivity varies by nut pair. Cashew-pistachio and walnut-pecan pairs show the strongest clinical cross-reactivity.
Cashew and pistachio are in the Anacardiaceae family. Very high clinical cross-reactivity (~50% co-allergy rate) is well-documented.
Walnut and pecan are in the Juglandaceae family. High clinical cross-reactivity documented.
Almond-hazelnut immunologic cross-reactivity exists via PR-10 proteins. Clinical co-allergy is less common than serologic overlap.
Lower cross-reactivity between almond and walnut compared to walnut-pecan. Shared 2S albumin epitopes may be involved.
Dairy proteins (casein, whey, lactoglobulin) are from the same source. Co-reactivity within dairy is expected rather than cross-reactivity.
Crustacean tropomyosin is the major cross-reactive allergen. Shrimp, crab, and lobster show strongest cross-reactivity. Mollusk cross-reactivity with crustaceans is lower.
Shrimp and crab tropomyosins share >80% sequence identity. Very high clinical cross-reactivity.
Crustacean tropomyosin cross-reactivity between shrimp and lobster is well-established.
Crustacean-mollusk tropomyosin cross-reactivity exists but at lower clinical rates than within crustaceans.
Shrimp-oyster cross-reactivity via tropomyosin is immunologically demonstrated but clinical co-allergy rates are lower.
Squid tropomyosin shows partial homology with crustacean tropomyosin. Clinical significance is variable.
Parvalbumin is the major cross-reactive fish allergen. Cross-reactivity is common among bony fish species, though clinical tolerance of individual species is possible.
Cod and salmon parvalbumins show immunologic cross-reactivity. Some patients tolerate one but not the other.
Tuna parvalbumin has lower homology to cod parvalbumin. Some fish-allergic patients tolerate tuna.
Seed allergens share some 2S albumin and LTP structures. Cross-reactivity between sesame, mustard, and other seeds is immunologically possible but clinical data is limited.
Sesame and mustard share 2S albumin allergens. Clinical cross-reactivity has been reported in some populations.
Celery and carrot are in the Apiaceae family and share PR-10 and LTP allergens. Cross-reactivity is part of the celery-birch-mugwort-spice syndrome.
Celery-carrot cross-reactivity via Api g 1 and Dau c 1 (PR-10 family). Well-characterized in birch pollen-allergic populations.
Egg white and egg yolk proteins can cross-react. Most egg-allergic patients react to egg white proteins (ovomucoid, ovalbumin).

Peanut (a legume) and tree nuts share some 2S albumin and vicilin-like structures. Clinical co-allergy occurs (~25-40% of peanut-allergic patients also react to tree nuts) but true immunologic cross-reactivity vs co-sensitization is debated.
Peanut-almond immunologic cross-reactivity via PR-10 and 2S albumin families has been demonstrated. Clinical co-allergy is variable.
Peanut-hazelnut co-sensitization is common but true cross-reactivity vs independent sensitization is not fully resolved.
Coconut is botanically a drupe, not a tree nut. Cross-reactivity with tree nuts is very rare but has been reported. FDA classifies coconut as a tree nut for labeling purposes.
